H0.text: Voltages are the quantities of the individual cells that sum to give the overall voltage of the battery.

H1.text: Currents of the individual cells sum to give the overall voltage of the battery.

H2.text: Resistances are the quantity that is summed to give the overall voltage of the battery, which is therefore the sum of the resistances of the individual cells.

H3.text: Weights are the overall voltage of the battery, which equals the sum of the weights of the individual cells.

A4.text: The net emf of a cell is the difference between the emfs of its half-cells.

A5.text: If the cells are connected in series, the voltage of the battery will be the sum of the cell voltages.

A6.text: The total current is the sum of the currents through the individual components, in accordance with Kirchhoff's current law.

A7.text: If the cells are connected in parallel, the battery voltage will be the same as the cell voltage, but the current supplied by each cell will be a fraction of the total current.

A8.text: The total resistance of two or more resistors connected in series is equal to the sum of their individual resistances.

A9.text: Voltage between points can be caused by the build-up of electric charge (e.g., a capacitor), and from an electromotive force (e.g., electromagnetic induction in a generator).

A10.text: In a static electric field, it corresponds to the work needed per unit of charge to move a positive test charge from the first point to the second point.

A11.text: The measured voltage output is lower than the no-load voltage when current is delivered, due to voltage drop caused by internal resistance.

A12.text: In use, the voltage across the terminals of a disposable battery driving a load decreases until it drops too low to be useful; this is largely due to an increase in internal resistance rather than a drop in the voltage of the equivalent source.

A13.text: Individual fuel cells produce relatively small electrical potentials, about 0.7 volts, so cells are 'stacked', or placed in series, to create sufficient voltage to meet an application's requirements.

A14.text: Cell potentials have a possible range of roughly zero to 6 volts.
